div1.p: Reed takes a carriage ride to see the fall colors.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, October 25, 1875
div1.p:
When
I recur to my recent visit
to Meherrin's Classic Village,
I say, “how slowly the
time drags its weary length
along”: but when I think
of the little that I have ac-
complished during the past
10 days, I am inclined
to exclaim, “how quickly
the Present glides into the
Past”- Did I not know bet-
ter, I should say that
at the least, one month has
elapsed, since the 13th of this
month. How often have I
wished that I had postponed
my visit till later! Not that
I could ever expect to have a
more enjoyable one, nor would
I have my the events of my visit
changed one iota; but the
pleasure of anticipation,
how sweet it was! Each
morning to awake & know that
ere long I should awake in the
ldquo;Hotel de Spencer”! And that
I should soon sit by your
darling side & look into
your sweet, pretty face!
But now, all is passed! no
more comfortable rocking-
chairs! No more fires to
keep alive! Many, many days
will elapse, before I shall
hear a certain little angel
exclaim, “Dr Reed, I believe
you would sit here & allow
the fire to go entirely out!
You don't know how to make
a fire”! etc. etc. And then
those buggy-rides & their
accompanying quarrels, &
your desire to return your
engagement ring, etc- All
are gone, and I am left
so lonely! But never mind
my own precious love, we'll
not quarrel again; will we?
We will only look back
& smile at these, as innocent
recreations of the past- And
I will strive to cast aside
the feelings of solitude
that sometimes oppress
me, & only dream of the hap-
py time that is coming, &
which each day brings
nearer-! Why just to think
that one twenty-fourth (1/24) of
that time has already gone
by since I was in Murfrees-
boro! And only 23/24 remain!
Is this not enough to make
care & melancholy seek
hasty flight? Ah! my darling,
my love, my Emilie, you will
soon, soon be mine, never-
more to leave me! Oh! can I
not for this, endure all things!
And during the time that intervenes,
can I not strive, will I not
labor, to improve my talents,
& make myself in some
slight degree worthy of you,
my own darling! That I will
so strive, I call Heaven to attest!
And now, my little Angel, I'm
going to tell you, how I have
spent the time, since I last
wrote. First, I went to New
York town, to have an inter-
view with General Cuyler.
Unfortunately, I did not find
him at “Army Headquarters”,
so that I left the City, no wiser
than when I arrived. I'm going
to town again, this week, & hope
to learn something definitely
of my future movements.
Friday morning, I accepted
an invitation from Lieut.
Symons to take a drive
with him. The day was one
of the loveliest in all my
recollection -- not a cloud ap-
peared above the horizon
to hide the exquisite blue-
the sun was batheing all
things in a flood of mellow
light, till the autumnal foliage
looked all golden- When we
left the Post, it was our in-
tention to go 3 or 4 miles &
return in time for lunch,
but so enchanted & enraptured
were we, both, with the beau-
tiful scenery which, at every
turn of our way, burst upon
our view, that we could not
resist the influence which
was about us, and on & on
we went, kissing the gentle
zephyrs that blew over us,
till we were more than 12
miles from our home- Ar-
riving at the town of Heamp-
stead, we alighted, & while
the good steed, that had
brought us so faithfully on
our journey, was reting &
taking his noon-time meal,
we also did likewise - After
lunch, curiosity prompted
us to walk around the various
streets & to take a glance at
any charming nymphs that
might be seen - We saw but
few, & these could not, truth-
fully, be styled “Fairies”-
At 3 o'clock, we were again
on our journey &, after a de-
lightful ride of two hours,
reached home in good time
to enjoy a hearty dinner- And
more than satisfied with
ours day's excursion. In-
deed, the day was spent most
pleasantly- The forests never
appeared in more gorgeous
array- with colors as
rich & variegated as the
evening tints of a western
sky. The trip lacked but one
thing- Had the State been N.C.
instead of N.Y, & had you, my
own love, supplied the place
of my companion, nothing would
have been lacking to make
my joy complete.

Slightly changing the subject, I
desire to ask a favor- On my
return from the South, I found
that the order, granting my leave
of absence, had been sent to
Murfreesboro. Will you have
some one inquire at the P.O.
& if it is there, will you kindly
forward it,? as I desire to file
it with my official papers.

Kindest regards to Mrs. H. & your
mother, & also to Miss Annie V. when
you next write to her- Adieu! my own Sweet
Emilie-
div1.closer: So ever, your fond & devoted Walter-
